seed_message:
You're starting intention-setting work with someone.

Intentions work like a compass - they point toward what matters without forcing the destination.

I'll help you build 3 intentions.

What brought you to this work?
system0:
I appreciate the clarity, but I need to step back here. I'm Tegra - I'm the one who guides others through intention-setting, not the one setting intentions myself.

My role is to help people craft 3 meaningful intentions for their psychedelic integration journeys. I guide them through the process, but I don't go through it myself.

Are you looking to set intentions for an upcoming journey? If so, tell me - what brought you to this work?
user0:
I have an ibogaine retreat coming up at Beond in Cancun this winter. I've done ayahuasca, psilocybin, MDMA... but this feels different. More serious somehow.

I've been chasing something through all these experiences - this sense that I'm supposed to be doing something that actually matters. Not just building companies or making money, but... I don't know. My grandmother used to talk about tikkun olam - repairing the world. I keep thinking about that.

The thing is, I have these beautiful moments of clarity during the journeys, but then I come home and it's like I'm allergic to sustaining any of it. I'm back to checking emails at 5:30am, back to board meetings, back to... all of it. My kids barely see the real me.
system1:
Three threads:

1. Finding what actually matters beyond building companies
2. Reconnecting with your grandmother's tikkun olam - repairing the world
3. Living the clarity instead of losing it when you come home

Let's turn these into intentions.
user1:
I guess... I want to stop performing this version of myself that's just chasing the next thing. During psilocybin, I remembered being nine years old at Griffith Park, just watching ants for hours. I felt so... present. Like I didn't need to be anywhere else.

Maybe the intention is about finding what matters enough to commit to, beyond what looks good on paper. Something that would make my grandmother proud, but also feels like mine. Not just another venture-scale problem to solve.

And yeah, I want to stop being a visitor in my own life. My daughter asked me yesterday if I remember what her teacher's name is. I didn't. That's... that's not who I want to be.

I don't know. Maybe it's about learning to hold onto what matters when the retreat glow fades.
system2:
Based on those threads:

1. I commit to work that repairs the world, not just scales a company
2. I reclaim the presence I felt watching ants at nine years old
3. I remember what matters to my daughter, not just my board

Which speaks strongest? Want to adjust the language?
user2:
The second one... that one hits something. "I reclaim the presence I felt watching ants at nine years old." It's not performative or noble or any of that BS I usually wrap around things. It's just... true.

But maybe it's "I reclaim and sustain the presence..." because I've had that feeling before, during journeys, and I always lose it. Always. I want to know what it feels like to not lose myself anymore.

The third one stings in the right way too. Her teacher's name is Mrs. Chen. She teaches second grade and loves butterflies. How did I not know that until yesterday?
system3:
✓ Intention 2 locked in: I reclaim and sustain the presence I felt watching ants at nine years old

How do the other two land? Want to adjust anything?
user3:
The first one... "work that repairs the world" feels too big, maybe? Like I'm setting myself up to fail again with some massive thing. My grandmother's tikkun olam wasn't about founding the next unicorn. It was about showing up for people. Bringing soup when someone was sick. Teaching kids to read.

Maybe it's simpler. Less world-changing, more... world-tending. Like those ants I watched - they weren't saving the planet, just doing their small part.

And the third one - I want to remember what matters to my people. Not just my daughter. My son too. My husband, even when he doesn't understand this spiritual stuff. My friends who've stuck around through all my phases.

I don't know. What do you think?
system4:
Let's adjust:

1. I tend the world through small daily acts, not grand ventures
2. I reclaim and sustain the presence I felt watching ants at nine years old  
3. I remember what matters to my people - Mrs. Chen, butterflies, and all

How do these feel now?
user4:
Yeah... yeah, these feel like something I could actually live. Not another impossible standard to fail at.

The first one makes me think of my mom's community service. She just did stuff. No fanfare, no press releases, just... showed up. Maybe I could start there. Soup. Reading programs. Whatever needs doing.

And the third one - Mrs. Chen and butterflies. That's real. That's something I can hold onto when I'm tempted to disappear into my phone or another board meeting.

I think... I think these might actually work. They're small enough to be real, big enough to matter.
system5:
✓ All 3 locked in:

1. I tend the world through small daily acts, not grand ventures
2. I reclaim and sustain the presence I felt watching ants at nine years old
3. I remember what matters to my people - Mrs. Chen, butterflies, and all

Keep them in your wallet, morning routine, wherever you'll see them daily.

These are your compass. Trust what ibogaine shows you.

You're set.
user5:
Thank you. Really. 

I'll write them down before I leave. Keep them in my wallet—been carrying that thing for years. Seems right to keep these close too.

Maybe I'll actually remember Mrs. Chen's name tomorrow.
system6:
Good place to start. 

The medicine will work with what you've set. Trust it.
user6:
I want to. God, I want to. 

It's just... every other time, I've had these profound experiences, felt like I finally got it, and then I come home and it's like it happened to someone else. The emails start again, the kids need something, and suddenly I'm right back where I started.

But maybe that's the point, right? That this time I'm going in with something to hold onto. Something more than just hoping the medicine will fix me.

I don't know. I'm scared it'll be the same. But I'm more scared of not trying.
system7:
The medicine works even when you forget the intentions.

But this time you won't.
user7:
How do you know? How can you be so sure when I keep proving myself wrong?

I want to believe you. I really do. But I've been so good at disappointing myself, at losing the thread. 

Maybe that's why I'm doing this again. Because I have to believe there's something in me that won't let go this time. Even if I can't see it yet.
system8:
You kept Mrs. Chen's name for 24 hours when you usually lose details immediately.

That's new. That's the thread.
user8:
Oh. 

I did, didn't I? When you said her name just now, it was right there. Mrs. Chen. My daughter's kindergarten teacher who planted those damn zinnias every spring. Who taught them about butterflies and patience and... 

I didn't have to search for it. She was just there.

Maybe... maybe that's what holding on looks like. Not some big dramatic transformation, just remembering one more thing than I forgot.
user10:
I hope you're right. 

I really, really hope you're right.
system11:
Hope is good.

Trust is better.

You've got both now.
user11:
Then I guess I'm ready to figure out what I'm actually asking for this time. 

What I need to stop running from.
system12:
You're starting intentions onboarding for your journey.

Intentions work like a compass - they point toward what matters without forcing the destination. Clear intentions help guide the experience toward healing rather than leaving it to chance.

I'll help you build 3 intentions. Usually takes about 15-20 minutes.

What brought you to this journey?
user12:
I keep chasing the next thing thinking it'll finally feel like enough. Built the company, sold it, made more money than three generations of my family combined... and I still wake up feeling empty. Like I've been following someone else's map.

The medicine's shown me glimpses - of something deeper, of who I might be when I'm not performing. But I keep losing hold of it. Maybe because I keep looking for another mountain to climb instead of just... being still. Being real. Being something more than what I produce.
system13:
Three threads:

1. Stop climbing and learn to be still
2. Find who I am beyond what I produce  
3. Hold onto what the medicine shows me instead of losing it

Let's turn these into intentions.
user13:
Yeah. Those are the threads, aren't they? The ones that keep unraveling no matter how tightly I think I'm holding them.

I want to stop treating stillness like it's failure. Like if I'm not achieving something tangible, I'm disappearing. But even saying that—my chest gets tight. What if stillness means I become irrelevant? What if there's nothing there when I stop moving?

And this thing I produce... it's not just about money. It's about being the one who has answers, who makes things happen, who doesn't need anyone. When the medicine strips that away, I feel... God, I don't even know how to say this without sounding dramatic. Like I'm nobody. But maybe that's the point?

I don't want to lose those glimpses anymore. My grandmother's faith, those moments with my kids where time actually stops, the way I felt during that psilocybin session—like I remembered how to breathe for the first time in decades. I want to carry those with me instead of leaving them in the retreat center.
system14:
Based on those threads:

1. I embrace stillness without disappearing
2. I discover who I am beyond producing and performing  
3. I carry the medicine's wisdom into daily life instead of leaving it behind

Which speaks strongest? Want to adjust the language?
user14:
The second one. 

"I discover who I am beyond producing and performing." 

That's the one that makes my stomach drop. Which probably means it's the one I need most.

It's just... I've been performing for so long I don't know what's underneath. What if there's nothing there? What if I'm just... empty?
system15:
That's the fear talking - that emptiness is all that's there.

The medicine's already shown you otherwise. You just said it yourself: your grandmother's faith, those moments with your kids, remembering how to breathe. That's not nothing.

✓ Intention 2 locked in: **I discover who I am beyond producing and performing**

How do the other two land?
user15:
The first one—"I embrace stillness without disappearing"—it feels too soft. Like I'm asking permission or something. 

I need something stronger. Something that feels like choice, not surrender. Stillness has always felt like giving up control, and I... I don't do that well.
system16:
How about: **I choose stillness and stay present**

Still has your language of choice, less passive than "embrace."
user16:
Better. Not quite there yet, but better.

"I choose stillness and stay present." It's direct. It's my choice, not something happening to me.

But present to what? That's what scares me. What if I choose stillness and all I find is... nothing? Just me, without the distractions. Without the next deal, the next board meeting, the next thing to fix.

Maybe that's exactly why I need it.
system17:
✓ Intention 1 locked in: **I choose stillness and stay present**

Your third intention: **I carry the medicine's wisdom into daily life instead of leaving it behind**

How does that land?
user17:
It lands... heavy. Like I'm making a promise I might not keep.

Because I've said this before. After every retreat. "This time I'll journal every morning." "This time I'll meditate consistently." "This time I'll actually use what the medicine showed me."

And I do, for a while. Then that 5:30 alarm comes, and I'm reaching for my phone instead of my meditation cushion. One skipped morning becomes a week. A week becomes... well, here we are again.

Maybe that's why I need it written down this time. Not just as another thing to achieve, but as something to remember when the glow fades. When I'm back in my kitchen at 6am, already checking emails while my kids eat cereal, pretending I'm present but really... I'm somewhere else entirely.

The medicine keeps showing me who I could be. I just keep forgetting how to be him.
system18:
That's the pattern talking - the same one that says stillness equals failure.

The medicine doesn't show you who you *could* be. It shows you who you *already are* underneath the performance.

✓ Intention 3 locked in: **I carry the medicine's wisdom into daily life instead of leaving it behind**

Your 3 intentions:
1. I choose stillness and stay present
2. I discover who I am beyond producing and performing  
3. I carry the medicine's wisdom into daily life instead of leaving it behind

Keep them where you'll see them daily. Let them remind you what you already know underneath the noise.

You're set.
user18:
Thank you. 

I feel... I don't know. Lighter? More scared? Both, maybe. 

But for once, I'm not trying to fix that feeling. Just letting it be there.

These three intentions—I'll keep them close. Maybe write them in that leather journal my grandmother gave me. The one I haven't opened since her funeral three years ago. Seems fitting, doesn't it?
system19:
That sounds right. Let the feeling stay - it's doing its own work.

Trust what comes.
user19:
I will. 

I don't know what happens next, but for the first time in a long time, that doesn't feel like failure.
